1.0  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Pursuant to the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.1 through 68.220 and Chapter 6.95, Article 2 of the California Health & Safety Code §25531 through §25543.3, this federal Risk Management Plan (RMP) is implemented as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.

The scope of this RMP is based on the guidance of the Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA), the city of Oxnard Fire Department, to ensure that all contemporary issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements.  With input from the CUPA, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) aqueous ammonia storage and handling system has been identified as the only process at the facility which triggers the CalARP RMP requirements.  This process was determined to be covered by Prevention Program 2 requirements.

On March 31, 2004, the amendment to the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule (Risk Management Program) under the Clean Air Act Section 112 ® (7) was signed. The amendment:

* Requires a correction to reportable information on chemical accidents be added to the RMP within six (6) months of the date of the accident;

* Requires that changes to emergency contact information be corrected within one (1) month;

* Removes the requirement to include a brief description of the off-site consequence analysis (OCA) in the RMP executive summary; and

* Adds three (3) RMP data elements.

EPA also amended the RMP*Submit format to expand the list of possible accident causes to include uncontrolled chemical reactions.  As part of this rulemaking, EPA also clarified that the five (5) year deadline for updating RMPs that were originally filed early (i.e., submitted before June 21, 1999), is June 21, 2004, with subsequent updates due every five (5) years thereafter.  This amendment became effective on April 9, 2004 when it was published in the Federal Register.  


1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is the policy of RRI E

nergy (RRI) that its employees, environment, property, and the general public be protected from any harm that may occur as a result of its operations.  To achieve this end, RRI strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.  

RRI implements its emergency response policies to comply with the overall corporate policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and of minimizing risk to the public. The safety of emergency and non-affected personnel is the highest priority; therefore, all procedures must be implemented in the appropriate manner (e.g., safely executed rescue and medical activities).  Protection of the environment is also a high priority.  Once the issues of life, safety, and the environment are addressed, the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery may be considered.


1.2  Facility Description

The Mandalay Generating Station is located at 393 North Harbor Boulevard in Oxnard, California at the western margin of the Oxnard Plain adjacent to the Pacific Ocean and approximately 60 miles west of Los Angeles, California (coordinates 34° 12¿ 26¿ north, 119° 15¿ 4¿ west).  The elevation of the facility is approximately 15 feet above sea level.  The nearest earthquake fault zones are the Malibu Coast-Santa Monica-Hollywood-Raymond Fault Zone 22 miles southeast of the site; the Oak Ridge Fault 3 miles north of the site; and the Ventura Fault 5 miles north of the site.

The station is located between a residential zone to the south (Oxnard Shores) and McGrath State Beach to the north. The main area covers approximately 60 acres and is bounded Harbor Boulevard on the east and by the Pacific Ocean on the west.  Appendix A contains site location/vicinity and overview maps.

The Mandalay Generating Station consists of two gas-fired steam turbine units, each rated at 215 MW (1990 mmBTU/hr), and one 130 MW (2510 mmBTU/hr) gas turbine peaking unit.  Ste

1.7  Management System Summary

The management system oversees the implementation of the RMP elements in order to manage the risk of a chemical release at this facility.  Pursuant to Title 19 CCR §2735.6, a program management system has been established to oversee the implementation of the RMP elements.  Management system components for this facility include:

* Organizational chart showing the positions with tasks involving the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system

* Roles and responsibilities of positions at the facility


1.8  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Following two (2) safety improvements made in 2004 (gas detection alarm upgrades, extra seismic restraints on pipes), there were no current action items identified during the 2009 Hazard Review ¿what-if¿ scenarios analysis.

1.3.1  Prevention Program 2 Elements

An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the whole chemical process. Using this approach the following components were considered in the evaluation in accordance with Title 40 CFR 68.48 through 68.60 (Subpart C) and Title 19 CCR §2745.6.  Program 2 includes all four (4) Program 1 elements and seven (7) additional elements:

Program 1 Elements (40 CFR 68.12 & 68.15)

* 5-Year Accident History
* Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis)
* Emergency Response Program
* Management System

Additional Program 2 Elements (40 CFR 68 Subpart C)

* Safety Information
* Hazard Review
* Operating Procedures
* Employee Training
* Maintenance Procedures
* Compliance Audits
* Incident Investigation

The various lines of defense that have been incorporated into the design and operation of the process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals have been evaluated and strengthened to assure their effectiveness at each level.  RRI uses the proactive identification, evaluation and mitigation for prevention of chemical releases that could occur as a result of failures in process, procedures or equipment. 
1.3.2  Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

In addition to implementation of the CalARP Prevention Program 2 elements, RRI has implemented specific safety features for the prevention, detection and control of releases of regulated (and other) substances at the RRI Facility.  The following are some of the control and detection equipment located in and around the facility to minimize the risk of an accident involving hazardous materials:

* Pressure relief and safety valves
* High level alarm

s and shutoffs
* Secondary tank containment (21,980 gallons, 150% capacity) 
* Emergency control stations (control room)
* Ammonia gas detector system
* Emergency shutdown systems (ESD)


1.4  Five-Year Accident History

There are no known EPA reportable incidents, system failures, or abnormal conditions due to a malfunction involving a release of regulated substances from the covered process involving on-site impacts or off-site impacts during the past five (5) years.  

There have been no accidental releases from the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Mandalay Generating Station in the past five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage  (Statute:  40 CFR 68.42).

am Units 1 and 2 are each equipped with Selective Catalytic Reduction Systems (SCR) for the control of oxides of nitrogen (NOX) emissions. 

The regulated substance used at the facility above California¿s threshold quantity (TQ) is aqueous ammonia (ammonium hydroxide, 29% by weight).  The ammonia is used in the SCR systems for control of NOx emissions from the boilers of Units 1 and 2. All other regulated substances onsite are in quantities below applicable thresholds.


1.2.1 Selective Catalytic Reduction

Aqueous ammonia [Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) 1336-21-6], 29% concentration by weight,  with a vapor pressure of 9.1 psig at 60°F is used in the SCR system to control NOX emissions from Units 1 and 2 as Best Available Control Technology (BACT).  The SCR system reduces NOX emissions by injecting vaporized ammonia (NH3) (CAS 7664-41-7) into the boiler exhaust gas stream upstream of a catalyst matrix.  Ammonia, NOX, and oxygen react on the surface of the catalyst to form harmless nitrogen (N2) and water vapor (H2O).  The low temperature catalyst is comprised of vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) on a ceramic substrate and operates within a normal temperature range of 600°F to 750°F.  Ammonia system diagrams are contained in Appendix B.


1.2.2  Regulated Substances

Aqueous ammonia is a toxic substance above the federal RMP and CalARP thresholds (19 CCR §2770.5, Tables 1 and 3, respectively).  No regulated flammable substances are present at the facility in excess of the threshold quantities under the regulation. All quantities of other materials are also below applicable thresholds.

* Aqueous ammonia, 29% by weight, 14,650 gallons (max), 32,000 pounds (max) as NH3

As shown below, the aqueous ammonia quantity on site exceeds CalARP and federal RMP thresholds. Appendix C contains MSDS documents for aqueous ammonia. 8974 was used to calculate a density of 7.48 pounds per gallon for the 29% ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) solution.

Vanadium Pentoxide

Vanadium pentoxide (trade name VNX) is the active SCR catalyst material. VNX is a solid deposited on a ceramic honeycomb material (less than 5% in matrix), the design of which promotes interaction with the exhaust gas stream within the SCR.  As such, VNX remains within the SCR and is not released to the atmosphere. This substance, therefore, meets the definition of an article (§2735.3) and is therefore exempted from the requirements of the CalARP program as per §2770.2(b)(3).  VNX is not federally listed under 40 CFR 68 Appendix A.


1.3  Summary of Accidental Release Prevention Program

Mandalay Generating Station uses aqueous ammonia in the SCR NOX reduction system.  Aqueous ammonia is a regulated substance and is used above the federal RMP and CalARP threshold quantities (TQ) therefore, RRI is subject to the RMP and CalARP requirements. The facility is coded  under the North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) as 221112, Fossil Fuel Electric Power Generation.

In accordance with the CalARP regulations and with the guidance of the Oxnard Fire Department as CUPA, it has been determined that the SCR system falls under the CalARP Prevention Program 2 requirement.   The SCR process uses an amount of aqueous ammonia that exceeds the state and federal TQ, therefore is subject to CalARP and the Federal RMP.
